Hydrogen System



* Liquid hydrogen tank and equipment is owned, operated, maintained by Messer company.

* SEH has deteailed SWP to operate the gas distribution system.

* H2 detectors with alarms located through the facility.

* Remote ESO buttons installed to shut the system down.

* PSI and PHA updated in November 2018.

* Seismic shutoff valve installed to stop system if seismic motion detected.

* NDT testing performed by outside contractor in September 2018.

* Berm exists between the storage tank and west property line.

* SEH has on-site ERT team.

* SEH removed one storage tank from the site in December 2018 to reduce the max quantity on site by 50%.

* SEH Uses MOC and PSUSR procedures for making changes to the hydrogen system.

_prev_prog_3.Description:
Hydrogen Chloride System - 

* Located in a limited access, locked building. 

* Building is continually scrubber and monitored by HCL detectors, that if in alarm, activate a water deluge system and shut the tube trailers down by closing all valves.

* Remote emergency shutoff buttons are available to shut the system down.

* Seismic shutoff system will stop the system and close all tube trailer valves if 0.3 g force is detected.

* Mechanical connections and valves are installed in exhausted enclosures.

* PSI and PHA updated in May 2020.

* NDT and external inspections performed by outside contractor in August/September 2018.

* SWP and detailed checklist used for disconnecting, connecting, and operating tube trailers.

* SEH has on-site ERT team.

* System is PLC controlled with alarms and interlock system.

* SEH uses MOC and PSUSR procedures for making changes to the HCL system.

_prev_prog_3.Description:
Trichlorosilane Bulk System



* System located in a limited access, locked building (B17).

* Building is continually scrubbed.

* Building contains HCL and H2 detectors that if in alarm, will shut the system down and close all valves.

* Building contains UVIR detector and smoke (Vesda) detectors that if in alarm, will activate AFFF foam system,

* Building is constructed with explosion panels an roof to vent pressure upwards.

* Berm exists between B17 and west property line.

* Seismic shutdown system will stop TCS system and close all valves if 0.3 g force is detected.

* Remote emergency shutoff buttons are installed to stop system.

* Mechanical connections are installed in scrubbed enclosures.

* Detailed SWP and checklists are used to offload TCS into the storage tank and operate the system.

* System is PLC controlled with alarms and interlock system.

* PSI and PHA were updated in November 2020.

* NDT and equipment inspections performedby outside contractor in September 2018.

* SEH has on-site ERT team.

* SEH uses MOC and PSUSR procedures for making changes to the TCS system

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Per the requirements of Section 112(r) of the Clean Air Act Amendments of 1990 as codified in Title 40 of the Code of Federal Regulations (CFR) Part 68, this Risk Management Plan (RMP) is submitted to the United States Environmental Protection Agency (U.S. EPA) in a timely manner for the SEH America Vancouver, Washington facility, which handles one or more regulated substances listed in Appendix A of Part 68.



1.1 STATIONARY SOURCE & REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED

SEH America owns and operates a silicon wafer manufacturing facility located in Vancouver, Washington.  The regulated substances handled by this facility are Hydrogen Chloride, Trichlorosilane and Hydrogen, which are considered hazardous by the United States Environmental Protection Agency (U.S. EPA).



SEH America manufactures high quality silicon wafers used in the manufacture of integrated circuits.   This facility manufactures a number of different types of wafers.



Hydrogen Chloride and Trichlorosilane are used in the manufacturing of epitaxial wafers.  The epitaxial process produces a thin layer of silicon on top of already polished wafers.  Hydrogen chloride is a gas that is used to etch the silicon wafer.  The maximum quantity of Hydrogen Chloride that can be stored or handled at this facility is 42,000 pounds.  (2 tube trailers of 21,000 pounds each).  Trichlorosilane is a liquid, with a maximum quantity that can be stored or handled at this facility is 78,637 pounds. Trichlorosilane is also used in the deposition of a silicon layer on top of a polished wafer.



Hydrogen is used in several processes in the facility.  It is frequently used as a carrier gas for other chemicals.  Hydrogen is stored as a liquefied gas at cryogenic temperature (-423 F).  The maximum quantity of Hydrogen that can presently be stored or handled at this facility is 11,812 pounds.  Messer Gas Company operates and maintains the Bulk hydrogen storage system for SEH.  SEH recently removed one liquid H2 storage tank from

the site, reducing the maximum quantity stored by 50%.



1.2 ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION & EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

SEH America has a proactive approach to prevent accidental releases and uses OSHA's Process Safety Management program as a guideline. SEH America greatly values all of our employees and we are honored to be members of our community. We engineer the highest standards of safety and environmental management into our systems. 



SEH America will respond with its Emergency Response Team to all emergency situations including leaks or suspected leaks. To be prepared for the unlikely event that a release does occur, SEH maintains a highly trained and always ready Emergency Response Team that works closely with the Vancouver Fire Department. 



1.3 GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM & 

CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

SEH America complies with EPA's Accidental Release Prevention Rule and applicable state codes and regulations.  The facility follows guidelines and recommended practices of the Compressed Gas Association for the safe handling and use of compressed gases such as hydrogen and hydrogen chloride. Numerous safety systems are used to prevent, detect, and mitigate releases of hazardous materials.  These include regular piping inspections, process area chemical detectors, process alarms and shutdowns, mitigation systems such as scrubbers and water sprays, and systems that fail in the "safe" position.  SEH has installed a seismic shutoff system to shut down the H2, HCl and TCS systems if seismic motion is detected.



1.4 FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

SEH America has never had a release of a regulated substance that has resulted in any deaths, injuries, off-site impacts or significant property damage on-site.



1.5 EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

SEH America has developed an emergency response program to prevent and respond to accidental chemical releases of hazardous materials.  The facility coordinates its response plan with members of

the local Fire Department and the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) of which SEH America is an active member.  SEH has developed and trained an emergency response team that is highly qualified to respond to releases of hazardous materials, and is available on-site 24 hours a day.  The team regularly trains with outside responders and performs regular drills with the local Fire Department and its Hazardous Materials Team.



1.6 PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

The following safety improvements have been planned for 2021 and beyond:



* Additional volunteer HAZMAT personnel will be recruited and trained to respond at SEH. 

* SEH will be attempting to reduce hydrogen quantities on site, possibly below the PSM/RMP threshold quantities.  SEH is investigating a steam-methane reformer H2 plant.

* Plant familiarization tours for new personnel for the Vancouver Fire and Police Departments are being conducted on a regular basis.

* SEH conducts annual Corporate safety audits with a team assembled by members from sister plants.  The HCL, TSC, and H2 systems are reviewed in detail.   



SEH America is committed to placing safety and the environment first. Our Safety & Environmental Policy stresses continuous improvement.
